content.title: Renovascular Hypertension
content.definition: Secondary hypertension caused by renal artery stenosis, leading to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The two major etiologies are atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis (ARAS) and fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD).

goldblatt_model.two_kidney_one_clip: Stenosis in one kidney, contralateral compensates
goldblatt_model.one_kidney_one_clip: Stenosis with solitary kidney or bilateral disease

raas_activation: Increased renin secretion from juxtaglomerular cells
Angiotensin II causes vasoconstriction and aldosterone release

clinical_clues: Flash pulmonary edema with bilateral RAS
Acute renal failure with ACE inhibitor initiation

learning_objectives: Differentiate atherosclerotic from FMD-related renovascular hypertension
Recognize clinical clues suggesting renovascular etiology
clinical_pearls: Flash pulmonary edema with preserved LV function is classic for bilateral RAS
ACE-inhibitor induced renal failure suggests critical bilateral disease or solitary kidney RAS
FMD responds excellently to angioplasty alone (no stent); ARAS benefits less predictably
Look for renal artery stenosis in patients with aortoiliac disease - often coexist
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Revascularization always improves blood pressure - Reality: Benefits are less predictable in ARAS than FMD
